title: If my joint bank account has been levied, is it possible to try and get the money back if it did not belong to me?
question: Being sued by a creditor, which I did not know about because they sent all the paperwork to my mothers' house (moved out 5 yrs ago). She lost the paperwork and didn't give it to me until the same week that the accounts were levied. The sheriff's office said I have until the 18th to file a claim of exemption.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Joint tenancy,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate
answers:
Mr. Swensen poses a great argument, but if the account was held in Joint Tenancy then each person on the account is technically the owner of 100% of the money in that account so you may have difficultly succeeding with such an argument.

Ms. Marsh like Mr. Swensen also strongly advises the questioner to consult with an attorney as this may not be a do it yourself project.

Disclaimer. Ms. Marsh is an attorney licensed to practice in California. The information posted above is for general information, does not constitute professional legal advice, and does not create an attorney client relationship.

A claim of exemption is the procedure to fight the levy. The person making the claim of exemption must do so within the required time. Your question is a little confusing, but it sounds like the money which was levied belongs to your spouse and the judgment debt was incurred before you were married, which is an issue which may be raised in a claim of exemption. In addition, you may be able to have the judgment vacated if your were not properly served through an appropriate motion in the court that entered it. You should consult with an attorney to discuss the particulars of the matter and for any specific legal advice.
